title: Vienna: local trains missing from Wiener Linien
label: [Label(name="upstream üèûÔ∏è")]
body:
I suspect that this is not in the scope of this app, but I don't know where the data comes from, so I am still posting here in the hope that someone can point me to the relevant project.

In Vienna, Austria, local trains (S-Bahnen) are part of the public transport network and don't require a separate ticket, and I'd expect them to be included in searches (they are, for example, on the website of Wiener Linien, Vienna's public transit company).

I found the following issue. When long pressing the map to do a reverse geocoding, the resolved address is rather imprecise. See the following screenshot

Some addresses in the area were added within the last few months, so maybe the used data is not up to date?! But I wonder how that can be the case when querying Nominatim. title: Order regions by continents
label: [Label(name="cla-signed ‚úîÔ∏è")]
body:
This PR adds the ordering of transport network regions into continents and therefore an easier way of picking the requested region as suggested [here](https://github.com/grote/Transportr/pull/390#issuecomment-350249478) by @grote.

It is already working on my personal phone, here some screenshots:
![screenshots](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18088991/33900748-3294ed02-df35-11e7-8b1e-368f5b4056a9.png)

Before merging it in, I think we should discuss the following points:
* Should the continents present little icons at the left, something like [this](http://www.endlessicons.com/free-icons/africa-icon/) (see also their [Terms of Use](http://www.endlessicons.com/terms-of-use/)? Should they be in SVG or PNG format?
* As almost all `Region`s represent countries, shouldn't we rename them in code to `Country`?
* The continent list item design is, as for now, almost identical to (because copied of) the region's design. Any ideas on how to improve the distinction are very welcome!
* Should we use the [Wikipedia definition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_America) where Central America is part of North America or should we separate it as another subcontinent of America as defined in [Ibero-America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_America#cite_note-6)?
* I think it would be necessary to translate the continent names in the respective `strings.xml`

title: Feedback Transportr 2.0.0-beta1
label: [Label(name="question ‚ùì")]
body:
Hi,

thank you for developing Transportr, it is a great and very useful app. I've tried Transportr 2.0.0-beta1 on Android 6 and would like to give some feedback.

- Using the Spain provider (which based on Navitia data), I experience a strange bug. Every time I look up a street there is now a "0" added to the street name; this wasn't the case in earlier versions of Transportr.

![bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23173049/33079806-d1f96072-ced6-11e7-88e6-d941177a00a1.jpg)


- Selecting time and date of travel is a bit cumbersome. It's only one tap to access the time menu, but I am still missing the "+15" button which I found really helpful. There is a "now" button in the time menu, but I don't think this is necessary, because simply holding the time icon in the upper corner sets the time to now. 

- Changing the date of travel is a bit trickier: you have to select the time menu and then click again so that the calender view will open up. That seems a bit too complicated to me (I am aware of the option to select "today" and "tomorrow", but it is not always useful) and was easier with the old Transportr app.

- Setting the time to "arrival" or "departure" also has gotten more complicated, with the integration in the context menu. It should be possible to change that when selecting the time and date of travel.

- When starting the app it shows me the map, a search box, home and work option, favourites, and the latest connections I looked up. Then when clicking on an option (let's say the work option), the app takes me to another screen where these options (home and work option, favourites, and the latest connections) are shown again (until the current position is loaded or a starting point is selected). Is this behaviour intended? I find it rather redundant to show the same information twice.

The redesign with the new map is nice, but to me the app feels less simple and elegant than it was. 

I hope this feedback is helpful.

title: Save trips as Repeating Trips and notify on changes
label: [Label(name="enhancement üèóÔ∏è"), Label(name="unresolved ü§õ")]
body:
# Use case

I'd like to cover the following use case:

- A user regularly commutes from A to B, for instance every weekday from her home to her workplace.
- She wants to get notified if her regular trip is not possible or will be delayed, for instance because of construction works.

# Implementation and UI

I suggest the following implementation:

- First: implementation of #171 
- Then, at the same UI point where a single trip can be save, another option for this feature shall be there, for instance:
  - "Save trip"
  - "Save as repeating trip and notify on changes"

A click on the latter would open a new screen, with the following options:

- _Weekdays_ with 7 checkboxes from Monday to Sunday, with 5 checkboxes from Monday to Friday preselected
- _Notify on changes_ with 3 checkboxes 
  - 24 hours before
  - 12 hours before
  - 1 hour before

In the main menu, under _Recent Trips_ add a new item _Repeating Trips_. Click on it will list all saved repeated trips, with the ability to edit the weekdays and the time point when to check.

# Functionality

What Transportr would do:

- Fetch the connection with the saved _From_, _To_ and _Departure time_ at the set time point, e.g. 12 hours before.
- If the fetched result has a diff to the saved connection, create a Push notification which links to a screen with the newly fetched connection. Otherwise, do nothing.

title: Sorting algorithm for location search
body:
I'm living in Germany, using the VGS provider. I've always noticed that location search results were mindboggingly bad-sorted, that's because the API of my provider doesn't sort the results (e.g. when you searched for Town Hall, the result you actually expected was 15th place in the list, altough it is a literal match). This also introduces sorting by non-literal matches, using the Levenshtein distance. There is still much room for improvement in the search feature (caching, lazy evaluation, better sorting algorithms) but for people using providers that don't sort this is a huge improvement. 

Technical:
When collecting search suggestions, each station is added to a hashmap with a corresponding score (type Double, between 1 and 0). When displaying the new Data, the list is sorted by the updated scores.

How to reproduce:
1. Search for a route
2. Choose a train
3. Hit refresh
4. Hit "Into calender" or back

If the delay has changed after hitting the refresh button, you will notice this information does not get saved. Imagine the following situation:

Your train leaves at 8:00 and arrives at 8:45, you see it displayed this way in the connection list. You then tap the train and tap refresh. New delay information is available and shown on the screen. Your train now leaving at 8:05 and arriving at 8:50 instead. You tap "Into Calendar", but the calendar appointment generated is from 8:00 to 8:45 instead of from 8:05 to 8:50. You return to Transportr, which still shows the delay, and hit the back button, returning you to the overview. However, in the overview, the delay is again not displayed. You tap the train again, the delay gone until you do another manual refresh.

It took me a bit to realize what was happening and thus I have no screenshots to better display. I will try to get some next time I run into this issue.

title: Make vibrating optional, disable by default
label: [Label(name="enhancement üèóÔ∏è")]
body:
I noticed that https://github.com/grote/Transportr/commit/b6c5d2c0e0d9f8882836ea2184533b01e7c98b24 introduced vibrating on long-clicking an option.

If there is one thing I'd like to call an antifeature, it is this.

I'd recommend at very least disabling this by default for the following reasons:
- Basically not a single other Android app does this, which makes Transportr inconsistent with expected behaviour.
- It is annoying. I feel like a lab rat being punished for doing an action whenever my device vibrates when I do it. And yes, I know this is an opinion, but a very strong one of mine, and I will not upgrade beyond 1.0.0-beta2 in its current state (in normal circumstances, I simply uninstall apps who do things like this).

Instead of vibrating, I'd like to recommend to just show a toast. You want to direct the user's attention to a small, otherwise easy to miss change. Toasts are literally made for this specific purpose. On systems that support it, you could even use a snackbar with an UNDO button: https://www.google.com/design/spec/components/snackbars-toasts.html#snackbars-toasts-usage.

title: Improve Performance when Auto-Completing Locations
label: [Label(name="enhancement üèóÔ∏è")]
body:
We are working on a project called PersisDroid (http://www.cudroid.com/PersisDroid/) for detecting potential performance issues. Our tool could find performance degradation caused by improper usage of asynchronous executions.
  We find that in some cases your app may suffer a long processing delay.

Case 1:
  **Related source code**  Class: de.grobox.liberario.adapters.LocationAdapter function: performFiltering.
  **Circumstance**  It may take long to react when the user enters chars swiftly in the AutoCompleteTextView.
  **Problem**  The current implemention of performFiltering may take long to execute. Notice the AutoCompleteTextView processes the inputs and filters the content in a single handler. If the previous filtering procedure is not completed the new filtering procedure would be blocked. For example, if I input 'abc' consequently, the view would process 'a', 'ab' and 'abc' one by one. This may not cause trouble when each word could be processed instantly. But if the process is long outdated processing should be cancelled. 
  **Suggested modification** Design a cancellation mechanism for the Filter. It would be better to cancel the previous processing when new character is input. I would suggest a cancellation mechanism in the while loop of _"suggestLocations"_ function. 

Case 2:
  **Related source code** Class: de.grobox.liberario.fragments.DirectionsFragment function: onCreateView line: query_trips.execute();
  **Circumstance** Slow on querying directions multiple times.
  **Problem** The _execute_ function of AsyncTask would actually execute the multiple tasks in a sequential manner (after Android 3.0 HoneyComb). That means multiple queries would be queued to be executed. The outdated queries should be cancelled to release the pool resource. 
  **Suggested modification** Design a cancellation mechanism of _AsyncQueryTripsTask_ and cancel previous queries when new queries arrive.

title: Feature request: Open location of journey waypoint in external app
label: [Label(name="enhancement üèóÔ∏è")]
body:
Currently waypoints, such as a bus stop at the end of a walk, have no accessible location data associated with them, e.g. longlat, address, integrated map, etc.

A major improvement would be if long pressing on a journey waypoint brought up a menu with the option to open the location of that waypoint in a 3rd party app. e.g. long press on the Herrfurthstr. bus stop offered "open location with app...", which would pass the location to a mapping app such as osmand for viewing the location area.

No experience with android app internals, I assume its possible by special uri or message object. Presumably easier (and more featureful) than integrating usable maps into liberario itself.
